block.p: Nothing better illustrates the profound racial and social-class biases in our criminal justice system than your June 17 news article about the student at an elite boarding school who carved a sexual slur into the back of a fellow student, a few days after slashing another student. He received a suspended sentence and a few years' probation.

Nothing better illustrates the profound racial and social-class biases in our criminal justice system than your June 17 news article about the student at an elite boarding school who carved a sexual slur into the back of a fellow student, a few days after slashing another student. He received a suspended sentence and a few years' probation.

Compare this egregious example of white middle-class privilege with the likely fate of any inner-city youth who similarly pleaded guilty to such crimes: long years in jail, probably in an adult prison. The politically seductive campaigns to ''get tough on juvenile crime'' -- cruel, misguided and counterproductive to start with -- are made even more destructive by their racially selective implementation.
H. JACK GEIGER, M.D. New York, June 18, 2000
The writer is professor emeritus of community medicine, City University of New York Medical School.
